Yes, and you have mine, It would be nice if we could meet some time In the fall and go to the matinee some time. O, that would bo just fine! Ill call you up some time on the phone and make a date. YeB and Id be awfully glad If you come up and take luncheon with me some time, and bring the baby with you. Id love to have you. Any time, you know just call me and 111 be sure to be home. document.text: The m arriage of Miss Stephanie Anne Lucas of Richmond to Mr. Paul Douglas Harvey of Appomattox took place on Saturday, June 12, 1976 at 4 oclock in the afternoon in All Saints Episco pal Church in Richmond. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Edward Lucas of Richmond and the groom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Harvey of Appomattox. The Rev. Mann Valentine, VI, of Richmond officiated at the double ring ceremony. The bride, escorted and given in marriage by her father, wore a gown of ivory silk organza with empire bodice of re-embroidered Alencon Lace, portrait neckline of scalloped lace and long bishop sleeves with lace inserts and wide fitted cuffs of lace. Her A-Line skirt was accented with wide inserts of lace bordered at the hemline in scalloped lace, extending, all around the full circular chapel length Hbrnisw Her- veil was a matching Mantilla, finger tip length, attached to a cap of lace and seed pearls. Mrs. John Zunka of Char lottesville was matron of honor. Bridesmaids were Mrs. Denny Throckmorton of Covington and Miss Sallie Harvey of

document.text: Saturday was a gala day for Appomattox. Although the weather w a s threatening a large crowd came to town to help put oyer the Victory-Loan. Hon. H. D. Flood and Lieut. Luther Throckmorton, an over sea soldier, spoke in the Court house. A brass band from Camp Lee made music and the Victory Loaa went whizzing over the top. It is estimated by the banks that at least 20,- 000 more than our quota has been subscribed. Appomattox is t h e proud possessor of another flag and is again on the map in Royal Blue figures as going over the top. The Womens Committee pledged our quota long ago and they fully redeemed the pledge.

document.text: Richmond, Va.- The Virginia Elec tric and Power Company board of directors meeting here approved a 50,000,009 construction program for 1956, declared dividends on the common and preferred stock and an nounced the promotions of Jamts B. Hawkins, and George A. Spencer. Hawkins succeeds Robert J. Throckmorton, who died the latter part of January, as vice president of Vepcos eastern division, with head quarters in Norfolk. Throckmorton had held this key post for more than 20 years. Spencer was named assistant treas urer to succeed Arthur L. Clark, who was recently made personnel direc tor. Hawkins, who moved up from as sistant vice president at Norfolk, is a native of Clifton Forge and re ceived his B. S. degree in electrical .engineering in 1926 from Virginia Polytechnic Institute. Following graduation he was employed by Vir ginia Public Service Company which was merged into Virginia Electric and Power Company in 1944. He held various engineering positions until 1940 when he was made super intendent of operations in Alexan dria. In 1943 he was transferred to Charlottesville as manager of the Blue Ridge District. He became as sistant vice president of the eastern division in 1952. He is a Kiwanian, member of the Princess Anne Country Club and di rector of the Norfolk Chamber of Commerce and has been active in the Community Chest and the Red Cross in Charlottesville and Norfolk. Spencer, who resides in Ashland, was born in Waterview in Middlesex County, and received his education in the Richmond Public Schools. He was employed by Vepco in 1936 and has held numerous posts in the ac counting department since that time except for six years service as an officer in the U. S. Naval Reserve during World War II and the Ko- Continued op Page Eight

document.text: Plnchot Falls To Get Pardon. Although hacked by a petition from Gifford Plnchot, former Chief Forester n the United States Department of Agriculture, Governor Stuart declined to pardon Sherman Sneed, serving two years in toe State Penitentiary for grand larceny. Sneed is a colored man, and was convicted in the Hustings Court of toe city of Richmond. It ap pears that his mother was at one time a charwoman at the Forestry offices in Washington, and she interested Mr. Plnchot in the case. The Governor granted a pardon to Bettle Lee, colored, sentenced to one year in toe penitentiary by the Hus tings Court of toe city of Lynchburg Mr larceny. She has served about half of her time, and the pardon was recom mended by Judge Christian, who pre sided at toe trial, and by Common wealths Attorney Yancey, who prose cuted. The Governor refused to pardon Eu gene Dorsey, an Alexandria negro serv ing a life sentence in tbe penitentiary for toe murder of toe arti8t Walter Schultze. One negro was executed for this murder, but toe sentences of Dor sey and other accomplices were com muted by Governor Mann to life lm prisonment Gerald Stratton, a mem ber of toe State Penitentiary Board, has interested himself in toe case of Dorsey, and presented the- papers to toe Governor. Notwithstanding personal applica tions from John P. Branch, Bernard Lewis, George Bryan and Davis Bot- tom, Governor Stuart declined a par don hi toe case of Clarence E. Wood ward, serving a sentence of ten years in toe - penitentiary from Newport News for criminal assault. He has served about seven years of his term, and members of his family have been quite active in securing toe sympathies of those who sought his release. The Governor refused toe petition Mr a pardon for William Scranage, now serving a sentence of eighteen years In toe State Penitentiary for a murder committed in King George county. He has been In prison about six years. Thie petition was presented by C. W. Throckmorton. A pardon was refused to W. W. Wey- twelve months on the public  roads from the city of Norfolk for selling cocaine. A pardon waB refused William Lee, colored, sentenced to six months in the Richmond City Jail in default of bond, for trespassing on the property ot St. Andrews School. Tbe case waB tried in the Police Court, where suspicious circumstances in connection with the trespass and toe previous bad char acter of the prisoner led to toe justice requiring bead in toe sum of 100, which Lee wins unable to give. He ap pealed to toe Hustings Court, where toe trial court was affirmed.

document.text: Paul Douglas Harvey receiv ed his Bachelor of Science degree Sunday. May 11th in ceremonies at Hundley Stadi um, Hampden-Sydney College. He plans in the future to enter the School of Dentistry Medical College of Virginia in Richmond. Rebecca Penn Harvey re ceived her Bachelor of Science degree Saturday, May 17 at graduating exercises in The Mall at Longwood College, Fsrmville. Miss Harvey was married Saturday, May 24 to Joseph Denny Throckmorton of Hamp den-Sydney. They will make their home in Covington. Mrs. Throckmorton will teach third grade at Callahan Elementary School in Alleghany County.. They are both graduates of Appomattox High School and are the son and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford E. Harvey of. Appomattox.

document.text: Mrs. Ola A. Thorkmorton if  I -  Mrs. Ola Abbitt Throckmor ton, formerly, of Appomattox, died Monday in Bradenton, Florida. She was the widow of Luther Wright Throckmorton. Born in Appomattox, she was a daughter of the late Aurelius William Abbitt and the late Nancy Jane Tibbs. She was a graduate of State Normal School now Longwood College and taught in the Richmond City Schools. She is survived by a daughter, Mrs. Nan Thorck- morton Browning of Bradenton, Florida a sister Elanor Abbitt Scott of Appomattox two granddaughters, and a great grandson. Graveside services will be conducted at 11 a. m. Thursday in Liberty Cemetery, Appomat tox. The family suggests that those wishing to make contri butions consider their favorite charity.   if Robinson Funeral Home of Appomattox is in charge of arrangements.

document.text: Mrs. Ben Harvey and Mrs. Grayden Pollard entertained with a luncheon of bridal appointment Thursday, May 23, at The Columns, honoring Miss Becky Harvey. Miss Harveys marriage to Denny Throckmorton took place Saturday, May 24, in Appomattox Court House Pres byterian Church. Among guests present for the luncheon were Mrs. Clifford Harvey, mother of the bride Miss Sally Harvey, her sisters maid of honor Mrs. J. D. Throckmorton, mother of the groom Mrs. Lillian Harvey, grandmother of the bride Miss Lucy Martin, Mrs. Marvin Goin and Miss Judy Agnew, attend ants of the bride.

document.text: Mr. Daniel Browning and family, of Richmond, were visiting Mr. R. H. Browning at the Old Court House last week. Mrs. Norman Cheatham and daughter, Miss Alice, of Lynch burg, have returned home after spending several days with Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Cheatham at the New Appomattox. Quite a crowd of our soldier boyawho have seen service in the Rainbow Division are ex pected home this evening at 437. A warm greeting awaits our heroes. Lieut. Luther Throckmorton came home last week with his discharge and saw his baby for the first time. He met Oaptian J ack Peters here also who ex changed greetings and said they last saw each other in France. Both of the gentlemen look good. Mr. John P. Rector had a se rious fire at his place of busi ness Monday night at Spout Spring The fire started in the store part of the building about 9 oclock p. m., the other part of the building being occupied by Mr. Holmesy Inge, as a res idence. Young Mr. Rector has only been in business a few months and is said to have been doing a good business, and many expressions of regret are heard of his misfortune. He was insured for 7,000 on stock and building, which will not cover his loss. Mr. Inge lost his household effects,with out insurance. Mr. Rector will rebuild and start business again.

document.text: Florida - Mrs. Jerry A. Burke and Mrs. Abbitt Scott have received word that their brother-in-law, Luther Wright Throckmorton, 85, died in Bradenton, Florida, on Mon day, February 5. A native of Richmond he was the son of the late Charles W. Thorckmorton and Mary Anne Wright Throckmorton. He was educated in Richmond Public Schools, University of Rich mond, United States Naval Academy and University of Virginia Law School. He was a lieutenant in the heavy artillery in World War I and served in France for the duration of the war. For a number of years he was an attorney with the Bureau of Immigration and Nationaliza tion in New York City. He is survived by his wife, the former Ola Lee Abbitt, a daughter, Mrs. Thomas A. Browning, of B r a d e n t o n , Florida, two granddaughters, a great grandson a sister. Miss Lucy T. Throckmorton and a brother, Charles W. Throck morton, of Richmond a sister, Mrs. Lewis Taylor of Mech- anicsville, Virginia two nieces and a nephew. A graveside service will be  conducted on Thursday, eleven a.m., February 8, at Liberty  Baptist Cemetery by the Rev. Morey Peoples, Vicar of St. Annes Episcopal Church.

Goin of Hampden-Sydney, sister of the bridegroom Miss Lucy Martin of Appomattox and Miss Betty Agnew of Burkeville. 1 Mr. Throckmorton was his sons best man and ushers were Paul D. Harvey, brother of the bride, David A. H arvey, brother of the bride, both of Appomattox Marvin C. Goin of Hampden, brother-in-law of the bridfegfroom- Robert M. Cham bers of Farmville and Robert M. Evans of Richmond. After the ceremony Mr. and Mrs. Harvey entertained with a reception at the church fellowship hall. The bride is a graduate of Longwood College and the bridegroom is a graduate of Hampden-Sydney College. After a southern wedding trip the couple will live in Covington, Virginia.

The Cox family and Mrs. Throckmorton entertained with string music and singing. iMr. and Mrs. Calvin Robinson will leave tomorrow for Old Point, where they will spend the week-end. Mrs. Robinson, Chairman, Third Dis trict of the Virginia Division, United Daughters of the Confeder acy, will attend a State Executive Board Meeting and banquet at the Hotel Chamberlain on Saturday. Also the Dedication of the Jefferson Davis Memorial Park at Fort Mon roe, in ceremonies by the General Organization of the U. D. C., which will fake place immediately after the adjournment of the Saturday morning dbssion. The Executive Board members will be joined at a luncheon by the U. D. C. General Officers and Distinguished Guests, following the Dedication Ceremon ies. Mrs. B. C. Baldwin, of Lynch burg, Past President of the Virginia Division, U. D. C., will accompany the Robinsons to Old Point. Birthday List

document.text: Democratic Mass-Meeting Saturday after a well-attend ed meeting of the Democrat of Appomattox county was held in the cpurthouse here, Col. Joe Button, of Richmond, presiding, the following reso lutions were adopted . By S. L. FergusonResolved we endorse the Democratic administration of our national government under the wise and statesmanlike leadership of our president, Woodrow Wilson. We esieem it a privilege as well as a duty to congratulate and felicitate our distinguished representative in congress, the Honorable Henry. D. Flood, for his conspicuous services to his country. He has aided with great ability and unflag ging zeal all the foreign and domestic policies of the chief of our party, and has been in the forefront in promoting the measures of this Democratic administration. We extend to him our warm and hearty sup port for another term in the House of Representatives. By L. W. ThrockmortonRe solved that the Democrats of Appomattox county in mass meeting assembled this 8th day of May, point with pride to the very efficient, able and capable officers of this county, and eachof the magisteriol districts hereof, and of the efficient, progressive and economic ad ministration which the Demo cratic party, through its officers has given to the taxpayers and people of this county. By 8. L. Ferguson Whereas the death of the Senior Senator of Virginia, the late Thos. S. Martin, has occurred since the Democrats of this county last assembled, therefore be it now Resolved, that the Democrats of this county feel keenly his deathwill miss his able coun sel, characterized in State and National affairs with distin guished ability and recognized statesmanship. By R. F. Burke  Resolved that the seven votes to which Appomattox county is entitled in the Democratic State Con vention to be held in Roanoke, on the 19th of May, be cast by the Delegates who are present in that convention on all ques tions as a majority of the dele gates present may determine. By J . R. HorsleyResolved that the delegates from this county to the Roanoke conven tion be instructed to vote for the re-election of Hon. R. A James as chairman of the State Democratic committee and for the re-election of Hon. Carter Blass as member from Virginia on the National Democratic committee. By C. W. Smith  Whereas, the Democrats of Appomattox county have been fortunate in electing to the Legislature of Virginia a typical Virginia gentleman, a man of high character, broad experience intelligence, ability and sound legislative judgment, who has faithfully and efficiently repre sented the people of Appomat tox county during the last session of the Legislature, and among other measures has in troduced and secured the pas sage of some important State Road Legislation, Therefore, be it resolved by the Democrats of Appomattox county in mass meeting assem bled this the 8th day of May 1920, that we heartily endorse the course and career of the Hon. J . R. Horsley as our rep resentative in the House of Delegates of Virginia. By R. L. BurkeWhereas since the Democrats of Appo mattox county last met in mass meeting on Dec. 31st, 1918, at which time they called upon the Hon. S. L. Ferguson to be come a candidate for the State Senate, and Whereas, he bowed to the will of his countymen and friends, and laid aside bis personal considerations, and has been twice elected to the Senate of Virginia from the 18th District, and has ably, intelli gently, faithfully and efficient ly represented us in the extra sessioirof 1919 and the regular Vsssion of 1920, during the era of re-construction and re-ad justment following the world war, when the State and Nation called for the best statecraft of our ablest men who proper ly safeguard our institutions, and provide for the new order of things which must inevitab ly follow Therefore, bo it resolved by the Democrats pf Appomattox county, in mass meeting assem bled this the 8th day of May, 1920, that we believe that he is one of the ablest représenta tives it has had, and we hearti ly endorse the course of the Hon. S. L . Ferguson in the Senate of Virginia. The following delegates, with one-fourth vote each, were elected to the Roanoke con vention which meets on the 19th of M nyin that city H.j
